moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. d4 Bd7 5. d5
comment:
At this point I got the idea referred to in
my introductory remarks that my opponent was going to play a cautious and
defensive game. This made me feel pretty good, as I said.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. d4 Bd7 5. d5 Nce7 6. Qe2 a6 7. Bxd7+ Qxd7 8. c4 c5
comment:
Either locking the centre for the moment or giving
herself the choice (after dxc6) of a central break with d5 at some point.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. d4 Bd7 5. d5 Nce7 6. Qe2 a6 7. Bxd7+ Qxd7 8. c4 c5 9. O-O g6 10. Bd2 a5 11. Nc3 h6 12. Qd1 Nc8
comment:
The start of some complicated (To
me!) and patient manoevring. The Knight has access to better squares from d7
than from a7.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. d4 Bd7 5. d5 Nce7 6. Qe2 a6 7. Bxd7+ Qxd7 8. c4 c5 9. O-O g6 10. Bd2 a5 11. Nc3 h6 12. Qd1 Nc8 13. Qa4

Unexpected after preparing to fianchetto on g7.
Still the Bishop can support K-side pawn advances better from e7.

I have won a pawn, am attacking
her Rook and have doubled my own Rooks. I'm feeling pretty good about now!
